awd_titl_txt: Regularity and Singularity Formation in Swarming and Related Fluid Models
awd_abstract_narration:
Swarming is a commonly observed complex biological and sociological phenomenon. The internal interaction mechanism attracts a lot of attention in physics, engineering, biology, and social sciences. This project is devoted to developing a unified mathematical theory towards the understanding of the swarming dynamics, as well as other nonlocal models that share similar structures. These models are widely considered in fluid mechanics, meteorology, astrophysics, biology, and ecology. The study of the regularity and singularity formations of these equations will provide a firm theoretical foundation for these applications, and also help consolidate the validity of these models in describing the natural phenomena. 


The research will focus on understanding the nonlinear and nonlocal phenomena in swarming dynamics, and models having related structures in fluid mechanics. Three different but related models will be investigated. The first model is the Euler-Alignment system, which describes the flocking behavior in animal swarms. The goal is to develop a robust toolbox to analyze the nonlocal alignment operator and its balance with the drift nonlinearity. Similar behaviors are also observed in other fluid equations including porous medium flow, and surface quasi-geostrophic equations, which will be investigated using the same analytical techniques. The second model is the 2D inviscid Boussinesq equations. The global regularity is one of the outstanding problems in fluid dynamics. The idea is to construct solutions to capture the possible singularity formation, starting from some modified versions of the equations. The third model is the kinetic swarming system. The aim is to investigate the important relation between the kinetic equation and a variety of hydrodynamic limits. In particular, different alignment operators will be considered at the kinetic level. They are expected to lead to different macroscopic limits. All these three sub-projects will advance the mathematical understanding of nonlocal PDEs and related applications. They will also provide education and training to graduate and undergraduate students in this active field.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project mainly focused on nonlinear and nonlocal equations in swarming and related fluid models. These equations describe complex physical, biological and sociological phenomena that are commonly observed in everyday life. The understanding of the featured nonlinearity and non-locality is not only mathematically challenging but also has a variety of applications.

The first part of the research dealt with the Euler-alignment system modeling animal flocks. Different types of nonlocal alignment interactions were investigated. New analytical tools have been designed to understand the nonlocal interactions and the resulting emergent phenomena. The notable results include: (1) critical threshold phenomenon for the Euler-alignment system with weakly singular interactions, (2) the effect of misalignment interactions, (3) singularity formations in the presence of vacuum, (4) global theory on the Euler-alignment system with pressure, (5) the Euler-alignment system with attraction and repulsion.

The second part of the research is on general Eulerian dynamics in multi-dimensions. The global solution to the Euler equation is a longstanding open problem. Several simplified models are studied in this project that advanced the mathematical techniques in detecting possible singularity formations. Moreover, a new framework was established in this project on radially symmetric solutions to the Eulerian dynamics, providing a clean way to distinguish global smooth solutions and finite-time singularity formations. The theory applies to (1) the Euler-Poisson equations, (2) the Euler-alignment system, (3) the Euler-Monge-Ampere equations.

The outcomes of this project also extend to nonlocal models in hyperbolic conservation laws, in particular on nonlocal traffic flow models. Nonlocal look-ahead slowdown interactions were investigated, leading to intriguing phenomena of traffic jam avoidance. This provides mathematical insights into designing modern traffic networks. Numerical studies followed which support the analytical findings.

The project resulted in numerous activities, and engaged multiple collaborators, two graduate students, as well as three undergraduate students in an REU program.

Modified by: Changhui Tan
